dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, hey B, have you been following this whole Apple versus GrayKey saga? It's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, hey B, have you been following this whole Apple versus GrayKey saga? It's pretty wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally, A. I mean, GrayKey, right? They were the company governments and police were using to, uh, crack into iPhones.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally, A. I mean, GrayKey, right? They were the company governments and police were using to, uh, crack into iPhones.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uncloaked by Forbes in March, Atlanta-based Grayshift promised governments its GrayKey tech could crack the passcodes of the latest iOS models, right up to the iPhone X. From then on, Apple continued to invest in security in earnest, continually putting up barriers for Grayshift to jump over. Grayshift continued to grow, however, securing contracts with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and the Secret Service.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uncloaked by Forbes in March, Atlanta-based Grayshift promised governments its GrayKey tech could crack the passcodes of the latest iOS models, right up to the iPhone X.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And Apple's been fighting back hard, investing a ton in security. It's been this, like, constant back and forth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Apple's been fighting back hard, investing a ton in security. It's been this, like, constant back and forth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From then on, Apple continued to invest in security in earnest, continually putting up barriers for Grayshift to jump over.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it looks like Apple just dropped a pretty massive bomb. According to Forbes, GrayKey can no longer break passcodes on any iPhone running iOS 12 or above.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it looks like Apple just dropped a pretty massive bomb. According to Forbes, GrayKey can no longer break passcodes on any iPhone running iOS twelve or above.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Multiple sources familiar with the GrayKey tech tell Forbes the device can no longer break the passcodes of any iPhone running iOS 12 or above.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? [interrupts] So, like, it's completely useless now for those devices?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? So, like, it's completely useless now for those devices?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, not *completely*, but close. They can only do what's called a "partial extraction." So, like, just unencrypted files and some metadata.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, not completely, but close. They can only do what's called a partial extraction. So, like, just unencrypted files and some metadata.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On those devices, GrayKey can only do whats called a partial extraction, sources from the forensic community said. That means police using the tool can only draw out unencrypted files and some metadata, such as file sizes and folder structures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. That's a huge downgrade from, uh, what they were doing before, brute-forcing passcodes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That's a huge downgrade from, uh, what they were doing before, brute-forcing passcodes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Previously, GrayKey used brute forcing techniques to guess passcodes and had found a way to get around Apples protections preventing such repeat guesses. But no more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Apple just, uh, put up what Forbes is calling an "insurmountable wall." And the craziest part? No one actually knows *how* Apple did it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Apple just, uh, put up what Forbes is calling an insurmountable wall. And the craziest part? No one actually knows how Apple did it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, though, Apple has put up what may be an insurmountable wall. Multiple sources familiar with the GrayKey tech tell Forbes the device can no longer break the passcodes of any iPhone running iOS 12 or above... A mystery fix Though its clear Apple has locked GrayShift out, no one actually knows just how the iPhone maker has done it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild! Even forensic experts are stumped? I remember they were finding ways around Apple's stuff for a while.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild! Even forensic experts are stumped? I remember they were finding ways around Apple's stuff for a while.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Vladimir Katalov, chief of forensic tech provider Elcomsoft, has repeatedly uncovered weaknesses in Apple technology. But he was stumped too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Vladimir Katalov, who's usually great at finding weaknesses, he's like, "No idea." Could be anything from kernel protection to configuration profiles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the, uh, police reaction been? Are they just, like, throwing their hands up?

Give it time and I am sure a workaround will be developed ... and then the cycle will repeat. Someone is always building a better mousetrap, whether its Apple or someone trying to defeat device security.
